title: 111_hr3694
content: The Act may be cited as the "Removing Excess Litigation Involving Energy on Federal Lands Act" or the "RELIEF Act". Congress finds that the United States spends over $1 billion per day on importing crude oil, which is the largest wealth transfer in history. The country has significant oil and natural gas reserves in the outer Continental Shelf, but legal challenges by environmental groups delay or prevent access to these resources, costing the American public and economy. Expedited judicial review is deemed necessary to address this issue. Exclusive jurisdiction over causes and claims related to covered energy projects is granted to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. All causes and claims must be filed within 60 days of the action or decision by a Federal official, or they will be barred. SEC. 5. District Court for the District of Columbia must resolve all proceedings subject to section 3 within 180 days, taking precedence over other matters. Failure to comply results in dismissal with prejudice. SEC. 6. Only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court. SEC. 7. Deadline for appeal to the Supreme Court. SEC. 7. Deadline for appeal to the Supreme Court states that only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court. If a writ of certiorari is granted, the district court's judgment must be resolved within 180 days, taking precedence over other matters before the Supreme Court. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON SCOPE OF REVIEW AND RELIEF. Judicial review of Federal actions presumes administrative findings correct unless proven otherwise by clear evidence. Prospective relief must be narrowly drawn and minimally invasive to correct violations of Federal law. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. Any person filing a petition for judicial review under this Act must pay prevailing parties' fees and expenses unless the Court finds their position justified. SEC. 10. EXCLUSION. This Act does not apply to disputes between lease parties regarding lease obligations. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. A covered energy project refers to any Federal official's action or decision related to leasing Federal lands for energy exploration, development, production, processing, or transmission, including actions under such leases.
